course.name: Done is better - Build What Matters

questions.question: How should you treat unknowns?
options: As assets that guide inquiry and next steps
As weaknesses to hide from others
As reasons not to act until certainty
As irrelevant to the decision at hand

questions.question: Why is naming unknowns important?
options: It reduces the cost of not knowing and aligns others
It makes you look smart and in control
It is required by law or policy
It has no effect on outcomes

questions.question: What is a good way to communicate unknowns?
options: What you do not know yet, and when or how you will find out
Only what you know and skip the rest
Vague statements to avoid commitment
Nothing; keep them to yourself

questions.question: Saying "I don't know yet" in a project context is best described as:
options: Leadership: it builds trust and sets expectations
Weakness that undermines authority
Rude or unprofessional behavior
Unnecessary if you have a plan

questions.question: What is the risk of making decisions as if unknowns do not exist?
options: Surprises and rework when reality diverges from assumptions
Faster decisions with no downside
No significant risk in most cases
Higher confidence and team alignment

questions.question: In this framework, how do unknowns function as a map for next steps?
options: They show what to learn or validate next
They are a physical map of the project
They replace the need for a formal plan
They do not; unknowns are irrelevant

questions.question: Which behavior undermines trust?
options: Hiding unknowns to look in control
Listing what you don't know yet
Setting a date to revisit the question
Asking for input from stakeholders
